<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of spinlock:
```c
static int spinlock(void)
{
	struct metal_spinlock lock = METAL_SPINLOCK_INIT;
	const int threads = 10;
	int value, error;

	error = metal_run(threads, spinlock_thread, &lock);
	if (!error) {
		value = total;
		value -= spinlock_test_count * threads;
		if (value) {
			metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "counter mismatch, delta = %d\n",
				  value);
			error = -EINVAL;
		}
	}

	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
error = metal_run(threads, spinlock_thread, &lock);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the address of 'lock' is passed to worker threads that will acquire/release the spinlock, so the pointed-to object must be modifiable. Rule 8.13 requires pointers to be const-qualified only when the pointee is not intended to be modified; in this case the spinlock is intentionally mutable, so using a non-const pointer is appropriate. (If, hypothetically, metal_run/spinlock_thread did not modify the pointee, then the API should take a pointer-to-const and passing a non-const pointer could indicate a rule breach.)
